abstract: The February announcement that Arsenio Hall’s syndicated late-night show would return for a second season turned out to be both premature and mistaken.
snippet: The February announcement that Arsenio Hall’s syndicated late-night show would return for a second season turned out to be both premature and mistaken.
lead_paragraph: The February announcement that Arsenio Hall’s syndicated late-night show would return for a second season turned out to be both premature and mistaken. CBS Television Distribution, which owns the show with Tribune Media, has announced a cancellation because of a ratings decline among the viewers most advertisers pay for in late night, people between the ages of 18 and 49. (The ratings leader in that group is Jimmy Fallon on NBC.) Mr. Hall, left, who had a hit syndicated late-night show in the early 1990s, revived the franchise with some fanfare in September, and he scored some early impressive ratings. But the late-night scene had become intensely crowded, with as many as 10 shows fighting for a shrinking number of viewers. The ratings drop set in motion a pattern of downgrades from a host of local television stations, which began relegating Mr. Hall’s show to little-watched hours of the night. In February, his old friend Jay Leno appeared on the show with a letter confirming a second year. The ratings slide forced CBS’s syndication division to rescind that decision.

headline.main: Another Ending for Arsenio Hall
headline.print_headline: Another Ending for Arsenio Hall

abstract: Moving from suspicion of insider trading to proving a violation requires much more than just timely trading and vague connections, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
snippet: Moving from suspicion of insider trading to proving a violation requires much more than just timely trading and vague connections, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Insider trading is all about propitious timing. And trades by the golfer Phil Mickelson and William T. Walters, a high-rolling gambler, just before the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn made an unsolicited offer to buy Clorox in 2011 have all the signs of a potential violation: a quick increase in the stock price that made their risky call options worth millions of dollars. But timing alone is not enough to establish insider trading. So moving from suspicion to proving a violation requires much more than just timely trading and vague connections between a potential source and profitable trades.

headline.main: The Perils of a Circumstantial Insider Trading Case

abstract: Sprint and T-Mobile have settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal. | A maverick judge leaves his mark. | Valeant’s opaque business model has been revealed. | Assessing the effects of a multibillion-dollar penalty on BNP’s capital.
snippet: Sprint and T-Mobile have settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal. | A maverick judge leaves his mark. | Valeant’s opaque business model has been revealed. | Assessing the effects of a multibillion-dollar penalty on BNP’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Responding to a wave of consolidation in the telecommunications industry, the nation’s third- and fourth-largest wireless phone operators have agreed to a deal of their own. The operators, Sprint and T-Mobile, which have long contemplated a merger, finally settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal that is likely to be announced this summer, DealBook’s David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write. The merger would create a more formidable rival to the two largest wireless phone providers in the United States, Verizon and AT&T. Under the terms of the deal, Sprint, which is majority-owned by Japan’s SoftBank, would acquire T-Mobile for about $40 a share in cash and stock, a 17 percent premium to Wednesday’s price. Accounting for regulatory uncertainty, the early terms of the deal also include a breakup fee of more than $1 billion that Sprint would pay to T-Mobile.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Sprint and T-Mobile Near a Deal of Their Own

abstract: General Motors is recalling vehicles because a warning chime is inoperative and because air bags may not deploy in a crash.
snippet: General Motors is recalling vehicles because a warning chime is inoperative and because air bags may not deploy in a crash.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is recalling about 105,500 vehicles in two actions — one because a warning chime is inoperative and the other because air bags may not deploy in a crash, the automaker said. So far this year, the automaker has issued 34 recalls covering nearly 15.9 million vehicles across North America, including 13.9 million in the United States. The largest recall announced on Friday involves the warning-chime issue and includes about 69,500 of the automaker’s newest pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, including 57,500 in the United States. The models affected by the recall are the 2014 Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra light-duty pickups, the 2015 Silverado and Sierra heavy-duty pickups and the 2015 Chevrolet Tahoe, Suburban and GMC Yukon and Yukon XL S.U.V.s. The air bag problem affects 36,000 vehicles in North America, including 31,500 in the United States. The models covered by the recall are the 2012 Buick Verano and the Chevrolet Camaro, Cruze and Sonic.

headline.main: General Motors Recalls 105,500 Vehicles

In the 1932 book “Samuel Butler: A Mid-Victorian Modern,” he wrote: “He never liked me, nor I him; from my earliest recollections I can call to mind no time when I did not fear him and dislike him … I have never passed a day without thinking of him many times over as the man who was sure to be against me.”

abstract: Stents and sutures are not an obvious fit, Jeffrey Goldfarb and Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews write, and the savings and benefits from such a merger do not appear to justify a premium of nearly $10 billion.
snippet: Stents and sutures are not an obvious fit, Jeffrey Goldfarb and Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews write, and the savings and benefits from such a merger do not appear to justify a premium of nearly $10 billion.
lead_paragraph: The marriage of Medtronic and Covidien looks to be one of convenience. The $42.9 billion deal includes a premium that exceeds the estimated cost savings. Stents and sutures are not an obvious fit. And moving Medtronic’s headquarters from Minneapolis to Covidien’s Dublin base will not obviously cut the American company’s tax bill. Freeing up overseas cash is too shallow a reason to tie the knot.

headline.main: Medtronic-Covidien Deal Is a Marriage of Convenience

abstract: How can you make a pair of Sicherman Dice — that is, renumber a pair of dice so that they give you the same odds as a pair of standard dice?
snippet: How can you make a pair of Sicherman Dice — that is, renumber a pair of dice so that they give you the same odds as a pair of standard dice?
lead_paragraph: Our challenge this week is a classic by recreational mathematician Col. George Sicherman, who hit upon the insight in 1977. The resulting Sicherman Dice are a curiosity known to pretty much anyone who’s spent some time with recreational math. I reached Col. Sicherman by phone and asked him — How did he even think to look for something no one else had even considered?

headline.main: Col. George Sicherman’s Dice

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday handed two major defeats to the government of Argentina, which has been fighting with New York hedge funds over bonds that the country defaulted on in 2001. lead_paragraph: ICAHN TAKES AIM AT FAMILY DOLLAR  |  The activist investor Carl C. Icahn, who has a long record of aggressively lobbying corporate boards and management, has turned his attention to Family Dollar Stores, the discount retailer in which he holds a 9.39 percent stake, DealBook’s William Alden writes. In a letter to Howard R. Levine, Family Dollar’s chief executive, Mr. Icahn urged the company to self itself “immediately.” He also demanded that three of his representatives be added to Family Dollar’s board. If the company does not cooperate, Mr. Icahn said he plans to go directly to shareholders with an effort to throw out the entire board.

abstract: At first glance, “The Last Magazine: A Novel” by Michael Hastings would appear to lack relevance in the current media age, but even from the grave Mr. Hastings has demonstrated anew an ability to reframe the debate.
snippet: At first glance, “The Last Magazine: A Novel” by Michael Hastings would appear to lack relevance in the current media age, but even from the grave Mr. Hastings has demonstrated anew an ability to reframe the debate.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, “The Last Magazine: A Novel” by Michael Hastings would appear to lack relevance in the current media age. A fictional account of life inside a failed magazine — Newsweek — in a dying industry — print — written by a now-dead journalist, the book seems very much beside the point. And the march of history aside, does the world need another roman à clef from inside the world of Manhattan media, whose bottomless interest in itself is not generally shared by the public?

headline.main: A Novel Lays Bare Media Ills

lead_paragraph: Neil Barofsky, an old foe of the 2008 bank bailouts, has managed to secure a familiar role: watchdog for one of the world’s biggest banks, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. New York State’s financial regulator is said to be close to picking Mr. Barofsky, a former federal prosecutor, as the corporate monitor for Credit Suisse after the bank’s guilty plea to helping American clients evade taxes. Credit Suisse agreed to hire a monitor as part of a related settlement. Separately, a monitor was also installed late last year at BNP Paribas, the giant French bank suspected of violating sanctions provisions.

abstract: The reason that so many apologies seem unsatisfying is that neither side really wants the apology, David Greenberg writes in an Apology Watch column. But there are strategies for reaching authenticity.
snippet: The reason that so many apologies seem unsatisfying is that neither side really wants the apology, David Greenberg writes in an Apology Watch column. But there are strategies for reaching authenticity.
lead_paragraph: In 35 years as a corporate insider, adviser and critic, I’ve been on both sides of dozens of apologies played out in the public domain — and the most striking common denominator is how few of those apologies were either genuinely given or received. In fact, I’d suggest that one reason for supporting Dov Seidman’s call for an apology cease-fire is that the modern apology has strayed far from its purpose — acknowledgment and redress of a wrong — and is simply a tactic played out in a larger zero-sum game of winners and losers.

headline.main: Apologies Become a Tool, Not a Goal

snippet: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. said there was a type of government worker — a partial public employee — who could choose not to pay union fees.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court dealt a limited blow to organized labor on Monday by ruling that some government employees did not have to pay any fees to the unions representing them. But the court declined to strike down a decades-old precedent that required many public sector workers to pay union fees. Writing for the 5-to-4 majority, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. concluded that there was a category of government employees — a partial public employee — who can opt out of joining a union and not be required to contribute union fees.

abstract: The sitcom, which ran on NBC for five seasons, will return for at least 13 more episodes on Yahoo Screen.

lead_paragraph: As might be appropriate for a cult comedy, “Community” has been saved again from the cancellation crypt.

abstract: An air bag inflator that has been linked to millions of recalled vehicles and two deaths was also sold to the two Japanese automakers, Takata says.
snippet: An air bag inflator that has been linked to millions of recalled vehicles and two deaths was also sold to the two Japanese automakers, Takata says.
lead_paragraph: The Takata Corporation said Monday that its defective air bags, already responsible for the recall of more than three million vehicles worldwide, were sold to two additional automakers, Subaru and Mitsubishi.

headline.main: Faulty Air Bags From Takata Sold to Subaru and Mitsubishi
headline.print_headline: Takata Sold Faulty Air Bags to Subaru and Mitsubishi

abstract: Alcoholic beverages can make passengers unruly, especially when mixed with medications. The conditions for trouble, and diverted flights, are particularly ripe on international flights.
snippet: Alcoholic beverages can make passengers unruly, especially when mixed with medications. The conditions for trouble, and diverted flights, are particularly ripe on international flights.
lead_paragraph: When Joshua Konowe, a technology entrepreneur, took his seat in an emergency exit row on a flight to Belgium last fall, he was unaware that his seatmate had washed down an anti-anxiety pill with her glass of wine.

headline.main: When Airlines Serve Alcohol, and the Beverage Cart Requires a Bouncer
headline.print_headline: Beverage-Cart Bouncers

abstract: The move, which allows Pinnacle to collect a $163 million breakup fee, clears the way for Hillshire Brands to sell itself to Tyson Foods for $7.7 billion.
snippet: The move, which allows Pinnacle to collect a $163 million breakup fee, clears the way for Hillshire Brands to sell itself to Tyson Foods for $7.7 billion.
lead_paragraph: Pinnacle Foods said on Monday that it was terminating its merger agreement with Hillshire Brands, clearing the final obstacle for Hillshire to sell itself to Tyson Foods for $7.7 billion.

headline.main: Pinnacle Foods Cancels Deal With Hillshire

abstract: As the United States Marshals Service began notifying winning and losing participants late on Monday afternoon, many in the Bitcoin world were still trying to figure out who won and the what they paid.
snippet: As the United States Marshals Service began notifying winning and losing participants late on Monday afternoon, many in the Bitcoin world were still trying to figure out who won and the what they paid.
lead_paragraph: Since Friday, when the United States Marshals Service auctioned off nearly 30,000 Bitcoins, investors and Bitcoin enthusiasts alike have been eagerly awaiting the results. As the agency began notifying winning and losing participants late on Monday afternoon, many in the Bitcoin world were still trying to figure out who won and the what they paid.

headline.main: After Bitcoin Auction, Winning Bidders Remain Elusive

abstract: Twitter makes another acquisition of a mobile ad technology company. This one is meant to improve ad targeting.

lead_paragraph: Twitter on Monday announced that it had acquired TapCommerce, a start-up in Manhattan focused on advertising tailored to smartphone apps.

abstract: A long-running privacy lawsuit may damage the company’s efforts to expand its technology to the home, the body and vehicles.
snippet: A long-running privacy lawsuit may damage the company’s efforts to expand its technology to the home, the body and vehicles.
lead_paragraph: The United States Supreme Court on Monday allowed a case accusing Google of wiretapping to proceed, undermining the search company’s efforts to put a troublesome episode to rest even as it plans to become more deeply embedded in consumers’ lives.

headline.main: Supreme Court Rejects Google’s Street View Appeal
